results.title: Ball juggling and dribbling
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Pele: the master and his method”.
Briefly covers the career of Pele in an overview of the soccer skills that led to Brazil’s success in the World Cup competition. Describes the skills involved with ball juggling and dribbling, showing each in slow motion and in the context of an actual game in stop-motion. Suitable for upper primary and secondary years 7-12.

group.title: Pele: the master and his method

results.title: Golden age
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Peach’s gold”.
Using dramatised re-enactments as well as historical footage, Bill Peach investigates the developments on the goldfields that occurred within ten years of the first Australian gold rushes. No longer was it just the lone miner scrabbling away at the rockface - big companies and massive machines replaced the small digger, with more gold found deep underground. The entire population benefitted through the development of transportation methods such as coach lines and railways needed to move the greater volumes of material, and the growth of cities like Melbourne - a boom town built on gold.

results.title: Life on the goldfields
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Peach’s gold”.
Bill Peach presents a look at life on the goldfields after the Eureka stockade. It was a colourful but often violent time, where fortunes were made and lost in a heartbeat. Using dramatised re-enactments as well as historical footage, the point is made that not all of those who came to the goldfields were fortunate enough to realise their dream, however they almost always embodied the pioneer spirit. Out of this free-wheeling era emerged the beginnings of a new society.

results.title: Peach's gold
results.brief_description: Bill Peach describes how the discovery of gold changed the course of Australia’s history. Through dramatised re-enactments and historical footage, the effects of the new economic force on population, the location of towns, wealth generation, the development of transport networks and the introduction of a representative democracy are all investigated. In this series Bill Peach traces the story of gold from its earliest discovery to the early 1980s.
results.description: Bill Peach describes how the discovery of gold changed the course of Australia’s history. results.title: Land of gold
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Peach’s gold”.
Using dramatised re-enactments as well as historical footage, Bill Peach investigates the economic crash of the 1890s and the exhaustion of the goldfields at Ballarat and Bendigo. He describes how the less well known but far more productive goldfields at Coolgardie and Kalgoorlie rescued Australia from the depths of depression and continued to contribute to the country’s economy up to the early 1980s.

results.title: Finders keepers
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Peach’s gold”.
Employing dramatised re-enactments, as well as historical footage, Bill Peach presents a history of the discovery of the first lucrative goldfield in Australia. The discovery of the goldfield near Bathurst in New South Wales, was made by Edward Hargraves, John Lister and William Tom.

results.title: Eureka
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Peach’s gold”.
Through dramatised re-enactments, as well as historical footage, Bill Peach traces the events which led to the dramatic confrontation at the Eureka stockade, one of the key incidents in Australian political history. He investigates the issues behind the uprising between the miners, the police and the army caused by harsh and expensive licensing systems and describes how long-term effects eventually led to the introduction of safer and fairer working conditions.

results.title: Peach's Australia : Murray Riverboats
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Peach’s Australia”.
The Murray River has many problems, including pollution, the dwindling of its native fish, and the introduction of the European Carp, but the biggest problem has been in the threatened loss of its history. To Bill Peach, “the riverboats represent the most colourful and romantic part of that history, and the skeletons of riverboats are symbols of our failure to love and care for our greatest river. Written and presented by Bill Peach.

results.title: Peach's Australia : Chinatown: Dixon Street
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Peach’s Australia”.
Anti-Chinese riots on the goldfields caused many Chinese to shift to the cities of Sydney and Melbourne. Chinatowns sprung up and became the centres of their business and social life, cultural and racial ghettos, where the people lived and worked together for mutual help and protection. The film looks at Sydney’s Dixon Street where, over half a century ago, two-thirds of Sydney’s Chinese population lived.

results.title: Peach's Australia: Arnhem Land
results.creator_credit: Bill Peach, David Roberts and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Popular former ABC TV personality Bill Peach travels the length and breadth of Australia seeking out often little known facets of the country’s history and their relation to present day conditions in the particular areas.
In this episode, Bill Peach explores Arnhem Land and it’s history, as seen by the Aboriginal people who live there. The program was filmed at the Gove, Elcho Island, Deaf Adder Gorge, Murganella and other places within the Kakadu National Park and includes a visit to the oldest rock paintings in Australia.
